intro: Quercus lugdunensis, commonly known as the Gallic oak, is a deciduous tree native to western Europe. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The tree is characterized by its large, lobed leaves and produces acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and can reach heights of up to 30 meters. Quercus lugdunensis is valued for its ecological role and historical significance in European forests.
